page.title: 04Farming in the Common Market
page.content: Under the Farm and Horticultural development scheme farmers have been encouraged to produce a 6 year plan of improvements in a year by year progression. These might include installing new drainage or providing new equipment. Approved plans gain an extra 10% grant from the E.E.C. Bradley farm installed new milking parlours to increase its productivity. Now milk quotas have been introduced and the farmer has been told to cut down his production, he feels that his investment has been wasted. Many dairy farmers in the surrounding area have taken {compensation} to give up milk production completely. The Common Market's Intervention Scheme demands grain of a high quality and the authorities are slow to complete payments. Selling on the open market is more attractive.
